data.title: Robert Lepage
data.meta_description: News about Robert Lepage, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
data.text:
Critic’s Pick

Review: The Met Opera’s Next ‘Ring’ Will Be a Sea Change

Richard Jones’s bleak staging of Wagner’s “Die Walküre” in London offers a clean break from the extravagance of the Met’s most recent production.

By Zachary Woolfe

With a 7-Hour Saga, Robert Lepage Returns to Safer Ground

The Canadian director’s “The Seven Streams of the River Ota” is set for a world tour, after his most recent productions were embroiled in debates about cultural appropriation.

By Laura Cappelle

The Met Opera Cuts Back on Screen Time for Berlioz Next Season

Citing “technical demands,” the company will replace its revival of a video-heavy production of Berlioz’s “La Damnation de Faust” with concert performances.

By Michael Cooper

Critic’s Notebook

Bored of the ‘Ring’

Robert Lepage’s much-warred-over Metropolitan Opera production of Wagner’s “Ring” cycle now makes for decent drama. But it’s still not worth it.

By Zachary Woolfe

Critic’s Notebook

The Met Opera’s ‘Ring’ Works Best From the Cheap Seats

Robert Lepage’s production, with a notoriously noisy machine as its centerpiece, benefits from distance, which makes it quieter and more cinematic.

By Joshua Barone

Review: In the Met’s ‘Siegfried,’ Singers Transcend the Staging

The third installment of Wagner’s “Ring” has its problems. Robert Lepage’s production for the Metropolitan Opera doesn’t help. But the cast does.

By Joshua Barone

Review: The Met’s ‘Walküre’ Has a Cast Worth Bragging About

Robert Lepage’s high-tech yet stiff staging of Wagner’s “Ring” opera has returned, led by the blazing soprano Christine Goerke as Brünnhilde.

By Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim

Critic’s Notebook

The Father-Daughter Bond at the Heart of Opera’s Greatest Epic

At the core of the “Ring” is the relationship between Wotan and Brünnhilde. The Metropolitan Opera’s old and new stagings offer divergent approaches.

By Anthony Tommasini

Review: The Met’s ‘Ring’ Stops Creaking, but Still Doesn’t Work

Robert Lepage’s technically complex staging of Wagner’s four-opera cycle began rolling out on Saturday. While the set works, it’s still empty-headed.

By Anthony Tommasini

Review: In Robert Lepage’s ‘Kanata,’ the Director, Too, Plays the Victim

The Canadian stage director has seen some of his productions derailed by accusations of cultural insensitivity. In a new show in Paris, he can’t resist pointing to his own suffering.

By Laura Cappelle
